thread.title: Newspaper headlines: Fury over Trump's refugee ban
thread.title_full: Newspaper headlines: Fury over Trump's refugee ban

title: Newspaper headlines: Fury over Trump's refugee ban
text: Messenger Image caption The Observer leads with what it calls "global fury" in reaction to President Trump's move to temporarily ban migrants from seven mainly Muslim countries. His decision to suspend refugee admissions to the US, including an indefinite ban on Syrian refugees, has resulted in legal action, the paper writes. Image caption The Sunday Times reports a rift between President Trump and the Prince of Wales, over their views on climate change which the paper says could disrupt the president's state visit in June. Image caption The Sunday Express leads on Prince William and Prince Harry unveiling a statue of Princess Diana to mark 20 years since her death. It also claims the royals are on a "collision course" with President Trump ahead of his state visit this year, citing fears about "potential clashes when Trump, who rejects climate change, meets Prince Charles". Image caption The Sunday Telegraph leads with comments from former Northern Ireland Secretary James Brokenshire that there is a "disproportionate" focus on soldiers. rather than terrorists, in the system for investigating murders in Northern Ireland during the Troubles. Image caption The Mail on Sunday reports that NHS doctors have been told not to call pregnant women "mothers-to-be" because it might offend transgender people. It describes the guidelines from the British Medical Association as "astonishing" and "ludicrously politically correct". Image caption Former EastEnders star Ross Kemp faced a gang of armed kidnappers during filming for a documentary in Libya, the Daily Star Sunday reports. It says the actor-turned-journalist "feared for his life" as he was held at gunpoint during a 12-hour stand-off.
